1116271405715398656.text: 10/10 (small print: "And because users are so accustomed to constantly being required to enter their passwords they will do so on any old phishing site. That's why I need FIDO!")

1116271404427743232.text: 9/ Can someone think of a scenario for device-bound FIDO/U2F/Webauthn that doesn't boil down to: "But I need users to re-enter their password after 2 hours of inactivity in the browser tab, that's how it's always been done."?

1116271402737389569.text: 8/ If your authenticator hardware is bound to the secure enclave in the old macbook that just broke, you have to pull out the scratch codes, and fully lose the second factor advantage.

1116271401223294976.text: 7/ Logging in on a new device is where things get tricky. A hardware security key can provide a binding of account to service TLS certificate and therefore protect against phishing and other attacks even on blank-slate devices (e.g. in disaster recovery).

1116271399793041408.text: 6/ Logical access to the device is protected by local password/passcode/pin/face id/touch id/whatever, so it's totally fine to *not* require another password login per website.

1116271398236848128.text: 5/ Yes, the cookie is stored in the filesystem and vulnerable to a local attacker or malware, but at that point you have other problems. That's not what security keys want to protect against.

1116271397091848193.text: 4/ A logged-in session already provides all the protections a security key would provide: HSTS and cookie-secure flag means the bearer token is only, absolutely positively, ever transmitted to the correct party.

1116271395812589568.text: 3/ Both U2F and Webauthn are supposed to secure the login process. My basic principle is: If you're forcing the user to log in (with password) more than once per device (for example by expiring sessions after a time or on browser exit) you're doing it wrong.

1116271394600435712.text: 2/ The whole point with FIDO U2F security keys is that they're portable  from device to device. Intel has had an SGX based FIDO implementation  for some time  (https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/security/hardware/fido-support-white-paper.html …)  but it's the most useless thing imaginable.

1116271393333760000.text: 1/ Isn't Webauthn's support for platform authenticators entirely useless? Discuss.
